title: Urban Waste Collection and Recycling Drop-Off
content: A city’s waste management team operates trucks from a central depot (<loc_depot>) to collect garbage (linehaul) from residential areas (<loc_customer>) and drop off recyclables (backhaul) at processing centers. Each truck has a <capacity> limit for combined waste and recyclables. Residential pickups must occur before recyclable drop-offs, and each stop has strict time windows (<time_windows>) due to noise ordinances. Trucks end routes at the last recycling center, avoiding unnecessary returns. The goal is to minimize total distance while meeting all time and capacity constraints.

title: Same-Day Retail Inventory Rebalancing
content: A retail chain uses vans to redistribute excess inventory from overstocked stores (<demand_backhaul>) to understocked ones (<demand_linehaul>), starting from a distribution hub (<loc_depot>). Vans (<capacity>) must deliver goods before picking up returns, and each store has narrow time windows (<time_windows>) for unloading during off-peak hours. Drivers finish routes at their last pickup location. Optimize routes to reduce travel time and avoid stockouts.

title: Farm-to-Table Produce Logistics
content: A farm cooperative delivers fresh produce (<demand_linehaul>) to restaurants (<loc_customer>) and collects compost waste (<demand_backhaul>) for return trips. Trucks (<capacity>) depart from a central farm (<loc_depot>) and must complete deliveries before pickups. Restaurants impose tight time windows (<time_windows>) for deliveries to avoid kitchen disruptions. Routes end at the last compost drop-off point. Minimize spoilage risk by optimizing for the shortest routes within time constraints.

title: Blood Bank Supply Chain with Returns
content: A blood bank coordinates deliveries of fresh donations (<demand_linehaul>) to hospitals (<loc_customer>) and retrieves expired blood units (<demand_backhaul>) for disposal. Vehicles (<capacity>) start at the blood bank (<loc_depot>) and must adhere to hospital time windows (<time_windows>) for lab staff availability. Deliveries must precede pickups, and routes terminate at the final disposal site. Balance urgency and efficiency to save lives.

title: E-Commerce Reverse Logistics
content: An online retailer’s warehouse (<loc_depot>) dispatches vans (<capacity>) to deliver new orders (<demand_linehaul>) and collect returns (<demand_backhaul>) from customers (<loc_customer>). Deliveries must finish before pickups, and customers specify 2-hour time slots (<time_windows>) for returns. Drivers end shifts after the last return pickup. Optimize routes to reduce failed deliveries and fuel costs.

title: Pharmaceutical Sample Distribution with Expired Drug Returns
content: A pharmaceutical company distributes medical samples to clinics (<loc_customer>) from a central warehouse (<loc_depot>) using refrigerated vans (capacity: <capacity>). Each clinic has a specific demand for samples (<demand_linehaul>) and a time window (<time_windows>) for deliveries (e.g., during non-peak hours). After deliveries, vans collect expired drugs (<demand_backhaul>) from clinics but must finish all deliveries first. Vehicles may end routes at the last clinic to avoid unnecessary returns. The goal is to minimize travel distance while ensuring temperature-sensitive deliveries arrive on time and returns are handled efficiently.

title: Luxury Hotel Linen Service with Dirty Laundry Pickup
content: A linen service provider supplies fresh linens to high-end hotels (<loc_customer>) from a depot (<loc_depot>) using trucks (capacity: <capacity>). Each hotel has a strict delivery window (<time_windows>) (e.g., before morning rush) and a linen demand (<demand_linehaul>). After deliveries, trucks collect dirty linens (<demand_backhaul>) but must complete all drop-offs first. Vehicles may finish routes at the last hotel to reduce idle time. The challenge is to optimize routes for timely deliveries, avoid overloading trucks with both clean and dirty linens, and minimize fuel costs.

title: Art Gallery Exhibit Rotation with Fragile Returns
content: An art logistics firm transports artworks to galleries (<loc_customer>) from a storage facility (<loc_depot>) using climate-controlled trucks (capacity: <capacity>). Each gallery has a narrow time window (<time_windows>) for installations (e.g., during closed hours) and a demand for new exhibits (<demand_linehaul>). After installations, trucks retrieve fragile returned artworks (<demand_backhaul>) but must prioritize deliveries. Vehicles may remain at the last gallery for security reasons. The goal is to plan routes that avoid rush hours, prevent overloading, and minimize vibration exposure for delicate pieces.

title: Construction Material Delivery with Debris Removal
content: A construction supplier delivers materials (e.g., steel beams) to sites (<loc_customer>) from a yard (<loc_depot>) using flatbed trucks (capacity: <capacity>). Sites have time windows (<time_windows>) for deliveries (e.g., before crane operations begin) and material demands (<demand_linehaul>). After deliveries, trucks collect demolition debris (<demand_backhaul>) but must empty their loads first. Trucks may end routes at the last site to avoid empty return trips. The objective is to balance heavy loads, comply with site schedules, and minimize travel distance on congested urban roads.

title: Event Catering with Equipment Retrieval
content: A catering company delivers meals to corporate events (<loc_customer>) from a kitchen (<loc_depot>) using vans (capacity: <capacity>). Each event has a strict serving time window (<time_windows>) and food demand (<demand_linehaul>). After service, vans collect rented equipment (e.g., chafing dishes, <demand_backhaul>) but must complete all deliveries first. Drivers may finish at the last event venue. The challenge is to ensure hot meals arrive on time, avoid mixing fresh food with dirty equipment, and optimize routes across a city’s lunchtime traffic.

title: Mobile Vaccination Clinic Routing
content:
A healthcare provider operates mobile vaccination units that deliver vaccines (linehaul) to rural clinics and collect used syringes (backhaul) for safe disposal. Each clinic has a strict time window (<time_windows>) for vaccinations due to staff availability. Vehicles start at a central depot (<loc_depot>) with limited cold storage capacity (<capacity>). After the final stop, units remain on-site for next-day operations (open routes). The goal is to maximize coverage while ensuring:  
- Vaccines are delivered before spoilage.  
- Biohazard pickups occur after all deliveries.  
- No vehicle exceeds temperature-controlled capacity.

title: Film Production Equipment Logistics
content:
A studio coordinates equipment deliveries (cameras, lighting) to shooting locations (<loc_customer>) and retrieves rented gear (backhaul) from wrap-day sites. Each location has narrow time windows (<time_windows>) aligned with shooting schedules. Trucks (<capacity>) depart from the studio (<loc_depot>) and end routes at the last pickup location (open routes). Challenges include:  
- High-value equipment requires sequenced deliveries before pickups.  
- Time-critical setups for daylight filming.  
- Fragile items reducing effective vehicle capacity.

title: Industrial Gas Cylinder Distribution
content:
A supplier delivers full gas cylinders (<demand_linehaul>) to factories and retrieves empties (<demand_backhaul>). Factories (<loc_customer>) accept deliveries only during shift changes (<time_windows>). Specialized trucks (<capacity>) start at the plant (<loc_depot>) and park at final stops overnight (open routes). Constraints:  
- Cylinders must be delivered before safety inspections.  
- Empty retrievals cannot precede deliveries.  
- Hazardous material limits simultaneous loads.

title: Perishable Flower Market Supply Chain
content:
A floral distributor delivers fresh flowers to urban markets (<loc_customer>) in the early morning (<time_windows>) and collects unsold inventory (<demand_backhaul>) before noon. Refrigerated vans (<capacity>) depart from a greenhouse (<loc_depot>) and remain at markets for afternoon sales (open routes). Key considerations:  
- Deliveries must precede market opening hours.  
- Backhauls are time-sensitive to prevent spoilage.  
- Temperature control reduces usable capacity.

title: Tech Waste Recycling Collection
content:
An e-waste company deploys trucks (<capacity>) to:  
1. Deliver secure bins (<demand_linehaul>) to offices (<loc_customer>) during business hours (<time_windows>).  
2. Later collect filled bins (<demand_backhaul>) from the same locations.  
Vehicles start at a processing center (<loc_depot>) and park at final collection points (open routes). Critical constraints:  
- Bin deliveries must precede scheduled collection dates.  
- Hazardous materials limit mixing of linehaul/backhaul.  
- Time windows align with building access policies.

title: Mobile COVID-19 Testing and Sample Collection
content: A healthcare provider operates mobile testing units that visit designated sites (<loc_customer>) to conduct COVID-19 tests (delivering test kits, <demand_linehaul>) and collect samples for lab analysis (backhaul, <demand_backhaul>). Each vehicle has a limited capacity (<capacity>) for kits and samples, and sites have strict time windows (<time_windows>) for testing (e.g., morning rush hours). Vehicles start at a central lab (<loc_depot>) but end at the last site to avoid unnecessary returns. The goal is to maximize coverage while ensuring no vehicle is overloaded and all time windows are met.

title: Luxury Retail Pop-Up Inventory Rotation
content: A high-end brand rotates exclusive inventory between pop-up stores (<loc_customer>) and a central warehouse (<loc_depot>). Deliveries (new collections, <demand_linehaul>) must precede pickups (returned items, <demand_backhaul>) in each route due to fragile packaging. Stores have narrow time windows (<time_windows>) for deliveries (e.g., before opening hours). Vehicles (<capacity>) do not return to the depot after the final pickup. The objective is to minimize travel costs while adhering to time constraints and handling priority deliveries first.

title: Marine Wildlife Monitoring Equipment Deployment
content: Researchers deploy sensors (<demand_linehaul>) to monitor marine ecosystems at remote sites (<loc_customer>) and retrieve damaged units (<demand_backhaul>) using boats (<capacity>). Sites are accessible only during specific tidal windows (<time_windows>). Boats launch from a coastal base (<loc_depot>) but may remain at the last site for maintenance. Routes must prioritize sensor delivery before pickups and avoid overloading vessels. The challenge is to optimize routes for minimal fuel use while respecting tidal schedules.

title: Corporate Document Shredding and Secure Delivery
content: A confidential document service delivers empty secure bins (<demand_linehaul>) to offices (<loc_customer>) and collects filled bins for shredding (<demand_backhaul>). Vehicles (<capacity>) must serve offices within their operating hours (<time_windows>). Deliveries must precede pickups to ensure bin availability. Drivers finish routes at the last office, eliminating return trips. The goal is to plan efficient routes that guarantee all bins are serviced daily without capacity violations.

title: Festival Food Vendor Supply Chain
content: A central kitchen (<loc_depot>) supplies perishable ingredients (<demand_linehaul>) to food stalls (<loc_customer>) at a multi-day festival and collects unsold food (<demand_backhaul>) for composting. Stalls have tight time windows (<time_windows>) for deliveries (e.g., before peak hours). Refrigerated trucks (<capacity>) drop off fresh supplies first, then pick up waste, and park near the last stall to avoid depot returns. The objective is to minimize spoilage by optimizing routes for speed and capacity utilization.

Each stop has a time window (<time_windows>) for appointments and requires specific medical supplies (<demand_linehaul>). After treatments, some pets need follow-up visits, requiring the clinic to pick them up (<demand_backhaul>) for return to the central facility (<loc_depot>). Vehicles have limited medical supply capacity (<capacity>) and must complete all deliveries before pickups. Routes are open-ended, allowing clinics to end at the last stop.

content: A boat-based library delivers books to coastal communities (<loc_customer>) with strict docking time windows (<time_windows>). Each community requests new books (<demand_linehaul>) and returns old ones (<demand_backhaul>). The vessel (<capacity>) must distribute all books before collecting returns and can finish routes at the final community. Tide schedules create hard time constraints for service commencement.

content: During a multi-venue music festival, merchandise trucks (<capacity>) deliver inventory to stages (<loc_customer>) during load-in windows (<time_windows>). Vehicles may park at the last venue overnight without returning to the warehouse (<loc_depot>).

title: Mobile COVID-19 Testing and Sample Collection
content:
A mobile testing unit operates from a central lab (`<loc_depot>`) to conduct COVID-19 tests at `<num_customer>` clinics (`<loc_customer>`). Each clinic has a testing demand (`<demand_linehaul>`) and returns samples (`<demand_backhaul>`) for analysis. Vehicles (capacity `<capacity>`) must:  
- Deliver testing kits to clinics within their operating hours (`<time_windows>`).  
- Collect samples after completing deliveries (backhauls must follow linehauls).  
- End routes at the last clinic (no return to depot).

title: Luxury Retail Pop-Up Inventory Rotation
content:
A high-end brand rotates inventory between a warehouse (`<loc_depot>`) and `<num_customer>` pop-up stores (`<loc_customer>`). Each store requires new stock (`<demand_linehaul>`) and returns unsold items (`<demand_backhaul>`). Vehicles (capacity `<capacity>`) must:  
- Deliver items before store opening hours (`<time_windows>`).  
- Pick up returns only after all deliveries are complete.  
- Finish routes at the final store (drivers depart from there).

title: Marine Wildlife Monitoring Equipment Deployment
content:
Researchers deploy sensors from a coastal base (`<loc_depot>`) to `<num_customer>` marine sites (`<loc_customer>`), replacing old units (`<demand_backhaul>`). Each site has a narrow tidal time window (`<time_windows>`) for access. Boats (capacity `<capacity>`) must:  
- Install new sensors (linehaul) before retrieving old ones (backhaul).  
- Avoid overloading during simultaneous deployments/retrievals.  
- Remain on-site after final retrieval (no return to base).

title: Corporate Document Shredding and Secure Delivery
content:
A shredding service collects confidential documents from `<num_customer>` offices (`<loc_customer>`) starting from a processing plant (`<loc_depot>`). Each office has a pickup demand (`<demand_backhaul>`) and time-sensitive delivery of blank secure forms (`<demand_linehaul>`). Trucks (capacity `<capacity>`) must:  
- Deliver forms before offices open (`<time_windows>`).  
- Collect documents only after all deliveries.  
- End routes at the last office (no return to depot).

title: Festival Food Vendor Supply Chain
content:
A central kitchen (`<loc_depot>`) supplies `<num_customer>` festival stalls (`<loc_customer>`) with fresh ingredients (`<demand_linehaul>`) and collects expired stock (`<demand_backhaul>`). Vehicles (capacity `<capacity>`) must:  
- Deliver before stall prep times (`<time_windows>`).  
- Pick up expired items after stalls close (backhauls last).  
- Park near the festival site post-operation (open routes).

title: Mobile COVID-19 Testing and Sample Collection
content: A mobile testing unit operates from a central lab (<loc_depot>) to conduct COVID-19 tests at designated sites (<loc_customer>). Each site has a specific testing demand (<demand_linehaul>) for kits and a pickup requirement (<demand_backhaul>) for collected samples. Vehicles have a cold storage capacity (<capacity>) and must deliver kits before collecting samples. Sites have strict time windows (<time_windows>) for testing (e.g., morning rush hours). After the final pickup, vehicles return directly to the lab for analysis, avoiding unnecessary trips.

title: Luxury Retail Pop-Up Inventory Rotation
content: A high-end brand rotates inventory between a central warehouse (<loc_depot>) and temporary pop-up stores (<loc_customer>). Each store requires fresh stock (<demand_linehaul>) and returns unsold items (<demand_backhaul>). Vehicles (capacity <capacity>) must deliver new inventory before collecting returns, with time windows (<time_windows>) aligning with store opening hours. Drivers end routes at the last store to avoid empty return trips, optimizing fuel costs.

title: Marine Wildlife Monitoring Equipment Deployment
content: A research team deploys sensors (<demand_linehaul>) to marine sites (<loc_customer>) from a coastal base (<loc_depot>), later retrieving damaged units (<demand_backhaul>). Boats (capacity <capacity>) must deploy sensors before pickups due to cargo space constraints. Time windows (<time_windows>) are tied to tidal conditions. After the last retrieval, boats dock at the nearest port instead of returning to base, saving fuel.

title: Corporate Document Shredding and Secure Delivery
content: A shredding service collects confidential documents from offices (<loc_customer>) after delivering empty secure bins (<demand_linehaul>). Trucks (capacity <capacity>) start from a processing plant (<loc_depot>), follow strict time windows (<time_windows>) aligned with office hours, and prioritize deliveries before pickups. Drivers finish routes at the last pickup location, reducing idle time.

title: Festival Food Vendor Supply Chain
content: A central kitchen (<loc_depot>) supplies ingredients (<demand_linehaul>) to festival stalls (<loc_customer>) and collects unsold perishables (<demand_backhaul>) before spoilage. Refrigerated trucks (capacity <capacity>) must deliver first, with time windows (<time_windows>) tied to meal prep schedules. After the last pickup, trucks proceed to a disposal site, avoiding return trips to the depot.

title: Disaster Relief Supply Chain with Medical Waste Collection
content: A humanitarian organization coordinates emergency aid deliveries (food, water, medicine) to disaster-stricken areas (<loc_customer>) from a central hub (<loc_depot>). Vehicles (<capacity>) must deliver supplies (linehaul demand: <demand_linehaul>) within strict time windows (<time_windows>) due to urgent needs. After deliveries, they collect contaminated medical waste (backhaul demand: <demand_backhaul>) for safe disposal. Vehicles may end routes at the last pickup point (open routes) to prioritize rapid response.

title: Urban Furniture Rental with Returns and Installation Windows
content: A furniture rental company delivers sofas and tables to clients (<loc_customer>) from a warehouse (<loc_depot>) using trucks (<capacity>). Each delivery (linehaul: <demand_linehaul>) must occur within预约时间 windows (<time_windows>) for customer availability. After lease periods expire, trucks collect returned items (backhaul: <demand_backhaul>). Drivers finish routes at the final pickup location (open routes) to avoid redundant trips.

title: Fresh Seafood Distribution with Empty Container Retrieval
content: A seafood supplier delivers live lobster/crab to restaurants (<loc_customer>) from a dockside depot (<loc_depot>) via refrigerated vans (<capacity>). Deliveries (linehaul: <demand_linehaul>) must align with restaurant prep schedules (<time_windows>). After unloading, vans retrieve empty oxygen tanks and crates (backhaul: <demand_backhaul>). Vehicles may park overnight near the last pickup to reduce downtime.

title: Mobile COVID-19 Testing with Lab Sample Returns
content: A fleet of mobile testing units starts at a lab (<loc_depot>) to visit neighborhoods (<loc_customer>). Each unit (<capacity>) delivers test kits (linehaul: <demand_linehaul>) during designated hours (<time_windows>), then collects completed samples (backhaul: <demand_backhaul>) for lab analysis. Units remain at the final sample pickup point (open routes) to expedite processing.

title: Pop-Up Retail Inventory Swap with Vendor Time Slots
content: A fashion brand rotates inventory between pop-up stores (<loc_customer>) from a central warehouse (<loc_depot>). Trucks (<capacity>) deliver new collections (linehaul: <demand_linehaul>) during store setup windows (<time_windows>), then retrieve unsold items (backhaul: <demand_backhaul>). Trucks end routes at the last store to avoid empty returns, optimizing staff schedules.

title: Mobile Library Book Exchange with School Time Slots
content: A county library operates a mobile service that delivers fresh book collections to schools (<loc_customer>) and picks up overdue returns (<demand_backhaul>). Each school has strict time windows (<time_windows>) for visits (e.g., during recess or after classes). Vans (<capacity>) start from the central depot (<loc_depot>), deliver new books (<demand_linehaul>), then collect returns—always completing deliveries before pickups. Drivers end routes at their last school without returning to the depot.

title: Freshwater Delivery and Wastewater Collection in Remote Villages
content: A humanitarian organization supplies clean water tanks (<demand_linehaul>) to villages (<loc_customer>) and collects wastewater (<demand_backhaul>) for treatment. Villages have narrow time windows (<time_windows>) due to local schedules. Tanker trucks (<capacity>) depart from a regional hub (<loc_depot>), prioritize deliveries, then perform pickups. Vehicles remain in the field after final stops to reduce fuel costs.

title: Luxury Fashion Pop-Up Inventory Rotation with VIP Appointments
content: A high-end brand rotates inventory between pop-up stores (<loc_customer>) and a warehouse (<loc_depot>). New collections (<demand_linehaul>) must arrive before VIP shopping slots (<time_windows>), while unsold items (<demand_backhaul>) are retrieved afterward. Secure vans (<capacity>) follow strict "deliver-first" sequences and park overnight at the last store.

title: Medical Lab Courier Network for Diagnostic Samples
content: A lab dispatches couriers from a processing center (<loc_depot>) to clinics (<loc_customer>) to deliver empty sample kits (<demand_linehaul>) and retrieve time-sensitive biopsies (<demand_backhaul>). Clinics have strict drop-off/pickup windows (<time_windows>) tied to operating hours. Electric vans (<capacity>) optimize routes to avoid sample degradation, ending shifts at the furthest clinic.

title: Film Set Equipment Logistics with Shooting Schedules
content: A studio manages equipment rentals for multiple film sets (<loc_customer>). Trucks (<capacity>) depart from the storage facility (<loc_depot>), deliver cameras/lights (<demand_linehaul>) before shooting starts (<time_windows>), and collect used gear (<demand_backhaul>) after wrap-up. Vehicles stay on-site overnight to avoid disrupting nighttime shoots.

title: Mobile COVID-19 Testing and Sample Collection
content: A fleet of mobile testing vans starts from a central lab (<loc_depot>) to conduct COVID-19 tests at designated sites (<loc_customer>). Each van has a limited testing capacity (<capacity>) and must collect samples within strict time windows (<time_windows>) due to lab processing deadlines. After testing, vans transport samples back to the lab (backhaul) but may end their route at the last site (open route). The challenge is to maximize daily testing coverage while ensuring no van exceeds capacity and all samples arrive at the lab before expiration.

title: Luxury Retail Pop-Up Inventory Rotation
content: A high-end brand operates temporary pop-up stores across a city (<loc_customer>), requiring weekly inventory swaps from a central warehouse (<loc_depot>). Delivery trucks (<capacity>) must drop off new collections (linehaul) and retrieve unsold items (backhaul) within narrow time windows (<time_windows>) to avoid disrupting store operations. Drivers may finish routes at the last pop-up location (open route). The goal is to minimize travel costs while adhering to strict boutique scheduling constraints.

title: Marine Wildlife Monitoring Equipment Deployment
content: Research vessels depart from a coastal base (<loc_depot>) to deploy sensors (<demand_linehaul>) at marine sites (<loc_customer>) during optimal tidal windows (<time_windows>). After deployment, they collect data loggers (backhaul) from previous expeditions. Vessels have limited cargo space (<capacity>) and may remain at sea after final operations (open route). The objective is to optimize routes for fuel efficiency while respecting ecological observation timeframes.

title: Corporate Document Shredding and Secure Delivery
content: A confidential document disposal service uses armored trucks (<capacity>) to distribute empty secure bins (linehaul) to offices (<loc_customer>) during pre-arranged time slots (<time_windows>). Later, the same trucks collect filled bins (backhaul) for destruction but may terminate routes at the last client (open route). The challenge is to coordinate this dual operation without violating security protocols or time-sensitive document retention policies.

title: Festival Food Vendor Supply Chain
content: During a multi-day festival, refrigerated trucks (<capacity>) replenish perishable ingredients to food stalls (<loc_customer>) from a central commissary (<loc_depot>). Deliveries (linehaul) must occur during specific off-peak hours (<time_windows>), while empty containers are simultaneously collected (backhaul). Trucks may park near the festival after final deliveries (open route). The system must prevent ingredient spoilage by strictly adhering to vendor restocking schedules.

title: Corporate Document Shredding and Secure Delivery
content: A confidential disposal service visits <num_customer> offices (<loc_customer>) from a secure facility (<loc_depot>). Each client has designated service hours (<time_windows>) for delivering empty secure bins (<demand_linehaul>) and collecting filled ones (<demand_backhaul>). Armored trucks (<capacity>) must complete deliveries before pickups to prevent cross-contamination. title: Festival Food Vendor Supply Chain
content:
During a multi-day festival, a commissary kitchen (<loc_depot>) supplies <num_customer> food stalls (<loc_customer>) with perishable ingredients. Each stall has narrow restocking windows (<time_windows>) between meal periods for receiving fresh items (<demand_linehaul>) and returning unsold food (<demand_backhaul>). Refrigerated trucks (<capacity>) follow open routes to minimize refrigeration loss, with drivers finishing at the last stall. The challenge is balancing just-in-time deliveries with food safety constraints during peak attendance hours.
``` 

These scenarios emphasize:
- **Temporal precision** (medical samples, tidal windows)
- **Security/logistical constraints** (luxury goods, confidential documents)
- **Perishability factors** (food safety, marine equipment)
- **Asymmetric material flows** (test kits vs. samples, empty vs. full bins)
- **Open-route efficiencies** in time-sensitive contexts
